report_title: IBISWorld | Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Manufacturing in the US Sep 2023
executive_summary: Autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) manufacturers serve several markets, with the most notable being the US government, more specifically, the Department of Defense (DoD). The DoD is an essential downstream client for AUV manufacturers since they provide manufacturers with stability through contracts. The other two clients are research and oil and gas companies, which use AUVs for more commercial applications. During the period, AUV manufacturers have experienced strong demand from all downstream clients, but government contracts and oil and gas companies stood out the most.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising interest rates have restrained growth towards the end of the period
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In early 2022, the Federal Reserve announced that it would be increasing interest rates across the US economy to try and dial in the rampant, persistent inflation. Increasing interest rates have limited the expansion of industry operators as the cost of financing large projects becomes much more costly. This slowed down the pace of technological development as well, harming innovation. In addition to limited technological expansion, heightened rates have also slowed concentration at the top, as mergers and acquisitions have become much more costly. Increasing interest rates have affected downstream demand for oil and gas companies, scientific research and other smaller markets that are all sensitive to interest rate changes. Demand is set to fall across many downstream markets in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Falling government spending during 2021 harmed the growth of manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: AUV manufacturers make a significant amount of their revenue from DoD contracts and government clients. In 2021 as the economy was booming, DoD spending, as well as demand for scientific research, fell. The falling number and frequency of DoD contracts caused a massive freefall in revenue for the year. Despite the slowdown in 2021, revenue grew again in 2022 as the economy began to contract, and contracts were on the uptick again. Revenue growth was also supported by significant increases in the commercial and research downstream markets. Oil and gas companies specifically needed AUVs for finding and securing new oil sources.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consolidation expected in the AUV industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New entrants demonstrating viable commercial potential are expected to be acquired by larger existing operators, leading to industry consolidation. Notable acquisitions over the past years include Huntington Ingalls's purchase of Hydroid Inc., Teledyne Technologies' acquisition of Ocean Aero Inc., and Boeing's acquisition of Liquid Robotics Inc. The industry landscape, however, remains relatively diversified, with no single company having a dominant share, providing ample room for competition and innovation. A significant reason why acquisitions were so popular during this period was the cheap debt available to companies looking to expand. However, as interest rates rise from a monetary policy from the Federal Reserve, acquisitions and mergers become a lot less likely.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The new period is expected to be marked by an expansion of companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: This industry is not known for expansions of establishment since most large companies dominate the government contracts since they have proven to be reliable and trustworthy for high-profile programs from the DoD. However, as technology becomes increasingly essential and commercial opportunities arise, new companies are expected to be able to find footing within the industry, whether it be with private research companies or massive oil and gas companies; barriers to entry may become easier as time goes on. In the public sector, government contracts are still expected to be challenging to secure. However, the need for more advanced technology opens space for newer companies to prove themselves in the face of the giants of the defense industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: R&D programs set to dominate industry spending
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Most of the defense funding will be funneled into research and development (R&D). The Large Displacement Unmanned Undersea Vehicle (Snakehead) and the Extra Large Unmanned Undersea Vehicle (Orca) are two major R&D programs expected to receive a sizeable portion of industry spending. These programs aim to develop large, long-range AUVs capable of launching from both surface ships and submarines for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance missions. In addition to publicly funded R&D, private R&D spending, namely for Scientific research and commercial uses, is expected to grow through the period. Oil and gas companies require highly advanced technology to scout new oil deposits under the ocean as more oil dries up. So, technology will need to grow as well as depth capabilities.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Commercial use is set to grow as a downstream client
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2028, commercial use of AUVs is expected to grow. Most of the demand from commercial clients comes from large oil and gas companies. The use of AUVs in deepwater exploration and oil and gas markets is forecast to be a key driver of growth, with AUVs gradually replacing ROVs for cost-efficiency and better performance. Scientific research is another piece of the commercial buyer downstream market, with oceanography, polar ice research, water sampling and fishery studies being the main subsections. The continued use of AUVs in this field is expected to support further growth of the industry through the end of the period.

industry_definition: The Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Manufacturing industry comprises establishments that primarily manufacture autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs), remotely operated vehicles (ROVs), hybrid underwater vehicles and unmanned surface vehicles (USVs). These vehicles are used for a variety of applications such as offshore oil and gas exploration, scientific research, and military operations.

positive_impact_factors: US oil and gas production index

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Research and development expenditure

key_trends: Increasing use of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) in offshore oil and gas exploration
Growing demand for AUVs in scientific research and environmental monitoring
Advancements in AUV technology, such as improved battery life, navigation systems, and sensor capabilities
Increasing adoption of hybrid underwater vehicles that combine features of AUVs and remotely operated vehicles (ROVs)
Expansion of military applications for AUVs in areas like mine countermeasures, intelligence gathering, and underwater surveillance

market_segmentation.segment_description: The military and security market accounts for over 60% of industry revenue.
The research market, composed of universities and research institutes, contributes significantly to revenue but its share has been declining.
The commercial market accounts for a smaller but growing percentage of revenue, with buyers in oil/gas and port/harbor operations industries.

products_and_services.product_or_service: AUVs operating in up to 200 meters of water
products_and_services.product_description: Small, lightweight AUVs utilized by military for shallow water operations like mine detection, disarmament, battlefield preparation. Also used commercially for tasks like underwater obstacle detection, harbor security, surveying. Account for largest share of unit sales and revenue.

Account for smaller portion of revenue. Used in military, scientific and commercial fields due to advanced features like imaging, navigation, sensors and communications equipment. Key players include Teledyne and Huntington Ingalls.

products_and_services.product_or_service: AUVs operating in greater than 1,000 meters
products_and_services.product_description: Hold second-highest revenue share, growing due to use by oil/gas industries and military for antisubmarine warfare and surveying. Expected further growth from replacement of early-adopted units. Major players include Bluefin Robotics and Boeing.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Driven mainly by military and security market
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The military and security market, primarily the Department of Defense, US Navy and DARPA, is responsible for over 60% of industry revenue. Funding is targeted towards R&D of AUVs for missions like antimine, surveillance, target acquisition, ISR and antisubmarine warfare.

The research market's share has been steadily falling as AUVs become more adopted in commercial and military operations. The commercial market's share is smaller but growing, with buyers in oil/gas extraction and port/harbor operations industries.

business_locations.location_description: New England accounts for the highest concentration of industry establishments, specifically Massachusetts. This region is sought after due to the presence of top engineering schools like MIT, Harvard, WPI, Yale, providing access to top engineers.

The West accounts for the second largest concentration, with California having the largest concentration in the US. Manufacturers benefit from top tech universities, providing a great source of R&D talent which is crucial for the business.

Within the Southwest, Texas holds the majority of the region's establishments as companies look to utilize the pro-business economic climate and access to educated talent shifting to cities like Houston.
Washington state has 8.0% of industry establishments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Compliance is necessary for operators to enter this industry. Manufacturers must adhere to strict regulations. Regulation for companies comes from both the US government, including the DoD, and the military branches that produce autonomous underwater vehicles.

Due to the advanced technological nature of autonomous vehicles, set-up costs are high. Manufacturing requires substantial technology, along with employees who are experienced enough to operate. Costs are high upfront and stay at a high level via technological advancement.

basis_points.basis_title: Ability to quickly adopt new technology
basis_points.basis_description: AUV manufacturers need to quickly incorporate the latest engineering processes, battery and propulsion technologies, advanced sensors and guidance software platforms to develop new products and keep pace with industry competition.

The high price tag of AUVs acts as a barrier to customer adoption; industry manufacturers that are able to achieve economies of scale (e.g. lower per-unit production costs) are able to more easily sell AUVs at a lower price and generate higher unit sales.
Revenue generated by government clients represents a large share of total industry revenue. Thus, it is important to be able to secure government contracts.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Government contracts add to the concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: A majority of the AUV product lines are solely purchased through government contracts and subcontracts. The presence of government contracts makes it difficult for new companies to set up, creating a problem for the industry, where only a handful of companies are contracted under the US government.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Classified nature bolsters the exclusivity of the industry
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most, if not all, the contracts between major players and the DoD are highly classified, which makes collaboration and competition extremely difficult. Because of this, only trusted major players can take on most of these contracts, further consolidating industry activity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High purchase costs have remained throughout the period
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: as volatility in international markets drove up prices for navigational instrument manufacturers. Global trade markets continued to exhibit volatility and slowdowns, further harming production and the overall performance of manufacturers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: An influx of demand bolstered profit during COVID
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is expected to hit 9.7% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: R&D efforts cause high wages across the industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: High wages also come with technologically advanced products, with wages set to account for 36.7% of revenue in 2023. Due to incredibly high investment in R&D from manufacturers, wages continue to remain high throughout the period.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: R&D efforts cause high wages across the industry
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: High wages also come with technologically advanced products, with wages set to account for 36.7% of revenue in 2023. Due to incredibly high investment in R&D from manufacturers, wages continue to remain high throughout the period.

FAQs.question: What are the key financial benchmarks for the Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Manufacturing industry?
FAQs.answer: According to the report, the key financial benchmarks are: Profit Margin of 9.7% (higher than sector average), Average Wage of $107k (higher than sector average), and Wages being the Largest Cost at 36.7% of Revenue.

FAQs.question: What are some key trends impacting industry costs?
FAQs.answer: Some key trends impacting costs are: Recent volatility keeping purchases high at 36.6% of revenue in 2023 due to supply chain disruptions; An influx of demand bolstering profit to 9.7% in 2023 despite wage pressures; High R&D investment leading to wages accounting for 36.7% of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: What do the financial ratios show about the industry's performance?
FAQs.answer: The financial ratios show trends like: EBIT/Revenue ranging from 13-16% over the last 5 years; Leverage ratio declining from around 20 to 6 recently; Current and quick ratios around 1.8 indicating adequate liquidity; Return on assets around 13-14% in recent years.

FAQs.question: What insights can be gained from the income statement data?
FAQs.answer: Key insights from the income statement: Cost of goods is a major expense around 56% of revenue; Wages are 9-14% of revenue; Advertising is around 1.5% of revenue; Net income has ranged from 7.9-13.2% of revenue over the last 5 years.

FAQs.question: What do the balance sheet ratios reveal about the industry's assets and liabilities?
FAQs.answer: The balance sheet ratios show: Cash and receivables make up a decent portion of assets; Inventories are low at 0.2% of assets; Intangible assets like patents are significant at 27.5% of assets in 2022; Debt levels have fluctuated but remained manageable with debt/net worth around 1.8-1.9 recently.
